awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Bioarchaeological and Biogeochemical Evidence in the Study of Ritual
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation project will examine life histories and ritual using bioarchaeological and biogeochemical analyses of skeletons from archaeological contexts. The research will contribute novel methods and perspectives concerning the role of rituals in ancient societies as well as the integration of osteological and chemical techniques to reconstruct human behavior. This project and the dissemination of its results will increase participation of traditionally underrepresented groups in the sciences and encourage future collaborations by involving the public in this project’s excavations, technical workshops, and public lectures. As workshop leaders for the Center for K-12 STEM Education at Tulane University, the investigators will integrate the project’s results into K-12 student curricular resources and workshops to showcase innovative research and broaden the education of groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields.

Human skeletal trauma represents direct evidence of conflict, making bioarchaeology, the study of human skeletal remains from archaeological contexts, well positioned to address the variability and significance of ritual violence in the archaeological record. The role of juveniles in such ritual contexts has been relatively understudied. Recently discovered skeletal assemblages suggest that such rituals played an important role in some past societies, yet the motivations for this remain unclear. The investigators hypothesize that individuals from outlying locations in a sociopolitical system were conscripted for ritual events as part of a strategy to maintain control over outlying regions. Continued excavations and biogeochemical analyses of bones and teeth from skeletal assemblagews will be used to test this hypothesis and better understand the ways in which past societies justified incorporation of juveniles in these events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research supported by the National Science Foundation combined archaeological, osteological, and stable isotope analysis to investigate the role of human sacrifice in the development and expansion of the Chimú (1000/1100-1450/1470 CE) and Inka Empires (1450-1532 CE) in the Moche Valley on the north coast of Peru. Following the emergence of the Chimú Empire, leaders consolidated the north coast through militaristic campaigns and staged rituals to communicate their power. Less than a century later, the Inka Empire overthrew Chimú rulers and conquered the north coast. Recent excavations conducted by the Huanchaco Archaeological Program in the Moche Valley at the sites of Huanchaquito-Las Llamas and Pampa la Cruz documented hundreds of human victims sacrificed in a highly standardized manner by having their chests cut open with a sharp implement.

This research aimed to detect why the Chimú and Inka Empires carried out the largest example of human sacrifice ever to be detected in the western hemisphere. Excavations conducted at the newly discovered sites of El Pollo and Montículo 2 found that human sacrifice not only occurred on a larger scale than previously known but was an enduring ritual practice that spanned at least 600 years beginning with the coalescence of the Chimú Empire and continued following Inka conquest. Analysis of the human skeletal remains from these sites found that children and adolescents were the preferred victims selected to be killed in this ritual and were sacrificed in a highly standardize manner. The stable isotope analysis of the bone, teeth, and hair selected from a sample of victims from Pampa la Cruz and El Pollo revealed that victim selection preferentially targeted individuals from multiple communities located within and outside the Moche Valley. Given these data, it is argued here that human sacrifice served to justify imperial expansion and emphasized power asymmetries by targeting individuals from newly conquered communities.    

The data and perspectives generated by this research contributes to anthropology and other social sciences by specifically addressing the unique ways society, the environment, and biological forces impact the lives of children and adolescents. Western notions of nonadulthood cannot be readily applied to other societies in the past and present. Indeed, these results of this project clearly indicate that nonadults maintained significant social importance in the Chimú and Inka worlds and were viewed as the preferred victims to be sacrifice during massive ritual events.

In addition to isolating isotopes routine examined in biogeochemical studies, this research integrated sulphur isotopes into reconstructions of victim life histories. Sulphur is known to occur naturally in the earth’s lithosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere, meaning that sulphur isotope values in the tissues of living organisms may be used as a proxy for reconstructing residential origins. This work provided the first sulphur isotope data for the Moche Valley which will be essential for establishing sulphur isotope landscape maps for Western South America. These may be used by anthropologists, archaeologists, and other scholars to document the residential origins and mobility patterns of humans and animals in the past and present.

Although the arid environment of the north coast of Peru is conducive for the mummification of human remains, mummies are rarely studied due to the destructive nature of removing tissues to examine the skeleton. Stable isotope analysis of hair from mummified remains conducted in this research was minimally destructive, and it provided a rare opportunity to capture sequential changes in diet and mobility patterns during the months prior to death. The stable isotope analysis of hair conducted in this work showcased the benefits of utilizing this cutting-edge methodological approach in reconstructing the life histories of ancient individuals. 

Although the devastating effects of the Covid-19 pandemic inhibited the PI and co-PI from completing many of the broader impacts outlined in the original proposal, it presented several opportunities to explore novel ways to disseminate this research. The investigators were able to return to Peru to conduct archaeological excavations in the fall of 2022, but at that time the country still maintained many regulations to slow the spread of Covid-19. Nevertheless, the Huanchaco Archaeological Program was able to involve members of community by facilitating informal tours of the site and invited archaeological students from the Universidad Nacional de Trujillo to participate in excavations.

The approaches and results of this research have been integrated into the content of several undergraduate courses taught by the PI and co-PI at Tulane University. Zoom made it possible for the co-PI to organize online workshops for K-12 students in New Orleans and participate as a guest lecturer at other universities in the United States. The impacts of Covid-19 on many communities strengthened the co-PI’s resolve to amplify this project’s scientific impact, facilitate greater participation among groups underrepresented in biological anthropology, and improve scientific literacy of the public by developing creative ways to conduct outreach in her academic career.
